stem: An 82-year-old client with bipolar disorder and heart failure was recently placed on a 'Low Sodium Diet' and started on Hydrochlorothiazide (HCTZ). Based on the documentation in the Geriatric Polypharmacy & Electrolyte Survey tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Acute mental status changes in a stable psychiatric patient.
Background: Stable on Lithium for 30 years. New HF diagnosis 1 month ago.
Assessment: Client is reporting 'ringing in the ears' and has a coarse tremor.
Recommendation: Stat sodium and lithium check.

tabs.title: Polypharmacy Survey
tabs.content:
AssessmentResultInterpretation
Serum Sodium (Na+)129 mEq/L (Low)Critical Hyponatremia
Serum Lithium2.4 mEq/L (Toxic)Kidneys retaining drug
Diet History2g Sodium RestrictionDecreased Na+ intake
Medication ListHCTZ 25mg dailySodium-wasting diuretic

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 102/64, HR 92, RR 18, T 98.4Â°F. Client is lethargic.

actionOptions.text: Hold the next doses of Lithium and Hydrochlorothiazide (HCTZ)
Instruct the client to stop the low-sodium diet and resume normal salt intake
Encourage the client to drink distilled water only to flush the drug
Increase the HCTZ dose to 50mg to help the kidneys excrete fluid

parameterOptions.text: Serum Lithium, Sodium, and BUN/Creatinine monitoring
Neurological status, tremors, and tinnitus (ringing ears)
Daily measurement of fasting serum glucose
Presence of a positive Babinski sign

rationale.correct: This is Thiazide/Diet-Induced Lithium Toxicity (c2). Lithium and Sodium are 'cousins' in the kidney. When the body is salt-depleted (Low Na+ diet + HCTZ which wastes sodium), the kidneys 'grab' Lithium as a replacement, leading to toxic build-up (2.4). The nurse should hold the offending meds (a1) and reverse the sodium-depleted diet (a2). Key parameters: Serum levels (p1) and standard lithium-neuro toxicity signs like tremors and tinnitus (p2).
clinicalPearls: Lithium patients need 2-3 liters of fluid and a CONSISTENT sodium intake. Never restrict salt without a lithium dose reduction.
Tinnitus (ringing in the ears) is a classic 'toxic' sign of Lithium.
HCTZ is a major 'killer' drug-drug interaction for those on Lithium.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking the low-sodium diet is 'healthy' for an 82-year-old with HF.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: For someone on Lithium, a low-sodium diet is a death sentence. The need for lithium stability outweighs the minor benefit of salt restriction in this specific case.

mnemonic.title: Salt-Lit Law
mnemonic.expansion: Low Salt = High Lithium. High Salt = Low Lithium. Keep it level!
